title: July 2012 FQE - Paper 2 (MCQs)
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine and Surgery - Paediatrics Paper 2 (July 2012). Contains 60 Multiple Choice Questions.

questions.question: Which of the following investigations are routinely done in a child with haematuria? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Routine workup includes confirming hematuria (Urinalysis), ruling out infection (Culture), checking renal function (U/Es), and checking anatomy (Ultrasound). Biopsy is invasive and reserved for specific indications (e.g., persistent proteinuria, deteriorating function).

questions.question: Select the MAJOR criteria for Rheumatic Fever according to the Jones Criteria.

richContent.content:
Major CriteriaMinor Criteria
CarditisFever
PolyarthritisArthralgia
ChoreaElevated ESR/CRP
Erythema MarginatumProlonged PR Interval
Subcutaneous Nodules

questions.explanation: Major criteria: Carditis, Polyarthritis, Chorea, Erythema Marginatum, Subcutaneous Nodules. Polyarthralgia is minor. Osler's nodes are seen in Endocarditis.

questions.question: What are the cardinal signs of congestive cardiac failure in children? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Cardinal signs: Tachycardia (rest), Tachypnea, Cardiomegaly, Tender Hepatomegaly. Cyanosis depends on the defect.

questions.question: Which organisms are the main causes of acute rhinitis (common cold)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Acute rhinitis is viral. Common agents: Rhinovirus, Adenovirus, Influenza, Coronavirus.
questions.hint: Viral causes of upper respiratory infections.

questions.question: Which of the following are TRUE regarding Post-Streptococcal Acute Glomerulonephritis? (Select all that apply)

options.text: History of skin infection 2 weeks prior
Hypertension is a main clinical feature

questions.explanation: APSGN follows skin/throat infection. Features: HTN, Hematuria, Edema. ASOT confirms recent strep. Treatment is supportive (not steroids). Proteinuria is usually mild-moderate.

questions.question: Which regimen is a suitable first-line for HIV in a 6-month-old child (based on guidelines recommending NNRTI-based for low risk or historical context)?
questions.explanation: Efavirenz is contraindicated <3 years/10kg. Triple nucleoside (D) is less potent. Nevirapine-based regimens were standard for infants (though LPV/r is now preferred).

questions.question: Which condition is classified under WHO Clinical Stage 3 for HIV?
questions.explanation: Persistent oral candidiasis (beyond neonatal period) is Stage 3. Oesophageal is Stage 4.
questions.hint: Fungal infection in the mouth vs esophagus.

questions.question: Select the true statements regarding Neonatal Sepsis.

options.text: First line treatment includes procaine penicillin
Convulsions are an indication for lumbar puncture
Blood cultures are definitive in diagnosis
Home delivery is a predisposing factor

questions.explanation: Procaine penicillin is avoided in neonates (muscle damage/sterile abscess). First line is Benzylpenicillin/Ampicillin + Gentamicin.

questions.question: Which statements concerning jaundice within 24 hours of birth are true? (Select all that apply)

options.text: May follow Rhesus or ABO incompatibility
Neonatal hepatitis is a common cause
Kernicterus may occur if bilirubin is very high

questions.explanation: Day 1 jaundice = Pathological (Hemolysis). Hepatitis usually causes prolonged jaundice later.

questions.question: On examination of a newborn, which finding is pathological?
questions.explanation: Single palmar crease (Simian crease) is associated with Down Syndrome. The others are normal or benign birth trauma.

questions.question: Regarding Tuberculosis in children:

options.text: HIV status of the child is mandatory before commencing treatment
TB adenitis is the commonest form
All children with TB can be treated as outpatient
Infant of mother with open TB should get BCG immediately
Pulmonary TB is the commonest form

questions.explanation: HIV testing is standard. PTB is most common. Severe cases need admission. Infants of infectious mothers need prophylaxis (IPT) first, not immediate BCG.

questions.question: What are common causes of stridor in children? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Stridor indicates upper airway obstruction (Larynx/Trachea). Nasopharyngitis affects the nose (snuffles).

questions.question: Regarding Bronchial Asthma in children:

options.text: Has better prognosis than in adults (often outgrown)
IV Aminophylline bolus is the best initial management
On auscultation, the chest may be silent in severe attacks

questions.explanation: Silent chest = Danger. Nebulized salbutamol is 1st line. Aminophylline is 2nd/3rd line due to safety profile.
questions.hint: A silent chest is a bad sign.

questions.question: Select the correct statements about vaccination in children.

options.text: Measles vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine
BCG is safe in symptomatic HIV
In measles outbreaks, vaccination can start at 6 months

questions.explanation: Measles is live. Outbreak control drops age to 6m. BCG is contraindicated in symptomatic HIV. Pentavalent starts at 6 weeks.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions cause massive splenomegaly? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Tropical Splenomegaly, Kala-azar, Schistosomiasis, and Leukemia are the 'Big Spleen' causes in the tropics.

questions.question: Features of Severe Malaria in children include: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Is a major cause of mortality
Drug of choice is oral SP
Parenteral Artesunate/Quinine is treatment of choice

questions.explanation: Severe malaria requires parenteral treatment. Oral SP is for uncomplicated malaria/IPT.

questions.question: What are recognized complications of Mumps? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Mumps affects glands (Parotids, Testes/Orchitis, Pancreas) and CNS (Encephalitis).

questions.question: Which features are associated with Down's syndrome? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Flat head, heart defects, gut anomalies, and hypotonia are classic.

questions.question: A stiff neck (Meningism) may be found in: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: While Meningitis is the primary cause, Meningism (irritation without infection of meninges) occurs in pneumonia, malaria, and tonsillitis.
questions.hint: Not just meningitis causes a stiff neck.

questions.question: Which statement about Cerebral Palsy is true?

options.text: It progresses as the child grows
More common in term than preterm babies
Occupational therapy has a minimal role
There is always an identifiable cause
Some patients may lead a relatively normal life

questions.explanation: CP is non-progressive. It is more common in preterms. Therapy is crucial. Cause is often unknown (idiopathic).

questions.question: Regarding Anaemia in children: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Iron should always be given regardless of cause
Peripheral blood film helps determine the type

questions.explanation: Hookworm sucks blood. PBF shows cell size (micro/macro). Iron is bad for hemolytic anemias (overload) or active infection.
questions.hint: Only give iron if iron is missing.

questions.question: Identify the correct developmental milestones.
questions.explanation: Weight doubles at 5-6 months, triples at 1 year. Smile at 6 weeks. Crawl at 9 months.

questions.question: Which of the following may cause seizures in children? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Seizures have many causes: Febrile, Infectious, Metabolic (hypoxia, electrolytes), and Vascular.

questions.question: Which investigations are used for Sickle Cell Disease? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Electrophoresis is definitive. Sickling/PBF are screening/supportive. Bleeding time checks platelets.

questions.question: Which parameters are used in standard Growth Monitoring? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Waist circumference is not routine in basic pediatric monitoring.
questions.hint: Measurements found on the Road-to-Health card.

questions.question: Which of these are classified as EMERGENCY cases in Triage? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: ABCD emergencies: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (Coma/Convulsion).

questions.question: Facts about Birth Asphyxia: (Select all that apply)

options.text: May result in permanent brain damage
Results from insufficient oxygen to the brain
Severe preeclampsia is a risk factor

questions.explanation: Asphyxia is defined by low APGAR scores and hypoxia.

questions.question: Regarding Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): (Select all that apply)

options.text: Blood shunts from Aorta (Left) to Pulmonary Artery (Right)
Patients can often lead a normal life

questions.explanation: PDA is a Left-to-Right shunt (Acyanotic).

questions.question: Infective Endocarditis: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Benzathine penicillin prevents the predisposing rheumatic disease

questions.explanation: It can occur in healthy hearts (virulent organisms), but damaged valves are a risk. Bacterial causes predominate.

questions.question: Signs suggestive of Meningitis include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Raised ICP causes a BULGING fontanelle, not sunken.

questions.question: What complications are associated with Infants of Diabetic Mothers (IDM)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: IDMs usually have Polycythemia, not Anemia. They are big, have low sugar, and immature lungs.

questions.question: Diagnosis of Pulmonary TB in a child (2 years) relies on: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Keith Edwards Score uses FTT, Mantoux, CXR, History of Contact.

questions.question: Side effects of oral Iron therapy include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Iron upsets the stomach and feeds bacteria.

questions.question: Calculate the APGAR score: Heart Rate < 100 (1), Weak cry (1), Gasping respiration (1), Pink tongue/acrocyanosis (1), Low tone (1).
questions.explanation: Sum of scores: 1+1+1+1+1 = 5.

questions.question: Differentiate between Marasmus and Kwashiorkor features:
questions.explanation: Marasmus = Starvation (wasted but hungry). Kwashiorkor = Protein deficiency (swollen and sad).
